# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

In Julia, you can solve this problem as follows:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump = 3)
    if bump < -24 || bump > 24
        throw(ArgumentError("Bump value must be within the range of [-24,24]."))
    end

    # Calculate new DateTime with increased hours.
    dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date; bump = 3)
    throw(ArgumentError("Cannot operate on Date type. Provide a DateTime value."))
end
```
This function will work with `DateTime` types and throws an error for `Date` types. It adds or subtracts the given number of hours from a date time object. The argument bump defaults to 3 but it can be changed by passing the desired hour value as an additional argument when calling the function.
